title: Captain Proton's ray gun and jetpack controller
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is Captain Proton's gun from Star Trek Voyager. Also useful as a general purpose 1950s ray gun.

I made it by starting with a jpeg photo of a prop, tracing it manually in Inkscape, and then exporting some parts as paths and others as inflations using my inflatemesh plugin.

It would probably look better painted than just printed in blue, but then it might be dangerously confused for a real gun from the distance.

If the pegs don't fit well, sand them or resize them to 98%.

I am also including a slight remix of John Lewis's ("propaholic") Captain Proton chest plate as part of the same costume, a cylindrical knob for the top two adjustment dials, and a slight remix of the pointer knob by sb43201.

Revisions: Added knobs for jetpack. Added knurling. Added handle inset. Added pegs for joining halves. Improved gunsight.

title: EVERSORT 2x250ML BOTTLE ENCLOSURE FOR FACSARIA CELL SORTER
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
As with the 1x 250ml enclosure....The is for a FACSARIA II cell sorter and allows sorting to proceed using 2x Corning 250ml plastic bottles. As a consequence, the operator can sort for periods in excess of 6 hours at high flow rates in a sealed unit. Some assembly is required as the cup extension, adjustable arms and cup hat must be printed separately. Arms are adjustable to ensure a tight fit in all cytometers. This model is a prototype and will be printed in the near future. This enclosure will undoubtedly require streams to be set at high deflection given that apertures are set at extreme left/right positions to accommodate both bottles.

Update for V14 - have enlarged target apertures, have pushed back bottle seating position under module, have increased size of bottle covers. stream should not need deflection of >80 on either side.

print_settings.Notes:: Don't need supports if your printer is okay (doesn't have to be perfect) at bridging.

description.text:
I got tired of the injection molding clips breaking so I made this one to completely surround the heat sink. You need to slide the heat sink in as part of hot end assembly either from the top or the bottom depending on if you've mounted the block already. I slide it from the top.

I print this in ABS to it doesn't melt when printing but if all you print is PLA, making it out of PLA will likely be ok. Just saying, don't make this out of PLA and then print with ABS temperatures and expect it to not melt!

I put a small support in the model where the clip slides in which needs to be cut out. Doing this allows you to print with no supports so long as your printer is decent at doing bridges.

I made the mount holes a little smaller in case someone wanted to use smaller screws. Just drill them out if they are too small.

Depending on how accurate your printer is, you may need to sand the clip thinner down to 1.5mm.

The spacer is included in case you want to put space between the fan and the grill to keep the fan from touching the grill. Some fans don't need it. Mine did.

The clip should slide into one of the smaller slots at the top of the heat sink. Line up the heat sink to the bottom of the model to determine which slot is right. The bottoms should sit flush.

The spacer and the grill are not square so mind how the holes line up.

I have included the measurements of the heat sink this is designed for. The hotend can be found here:

https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B01M8QCKQF/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Flashforge Creator Pro 2015 Rear Filament Guide

description.text:
The Flashforge Creator Pro is notorious for yanking the filament off the spool and tangling it around the spool holder, causing filament jams. This Thing makes it pull filament from the center of the spool instead of the side, which prevents that type of jam.

These are quite common on Thingiverse, but most are designed for the 2016 Creator Pro, which has the filament tubes spaced farther apart and a different type of snaps than the 2015 version.

This is designed for the 2015 Flashforge Creator Pro and may fit some compatibles (QIDI Tech, CTC, etc.) but will not fit the 2016 Creator Pro. It fits the 'buckle' style mounts - see the pictures.

This is a remix of an awesome design by "Dr. Lex." Thanks!

description.text: Boxes for ISD1820 boards (two models).

I got myself a CR-10 and didn't like using those clips to hold the glass in place so I design something to put under the bed to hold the glass in place without getting in the way. Print both parts and install the holder part on the leveling screw in between the heating plate and the spring. The clip part fits on the corner and clips onto the holder piece. I'm working on one for the side where the power cable attaches. Let me know if something doesn't work right.

Warning!
Depending on the printer, the back clips might have to be modified slightly to fit past the uprights on either side of the build plate. I've adjusted the part files to fit better but they may still require some hand fitting. Check it on the printer before printing with them installed.

title: Laser Cut Case for Raspberry Pi & NanoSound DAC

description.text:
I found it difficult to design a closed case for Raspberry Pi , considering there are plugs on three sides. The project will be more complicated when you need to add extension boards.

So I try to keep things simple. It is an open design with 2 pieces of wood only. The case was tailor made to fit for my NanoSound DAC extension board. The covers are holding together by four 30mm nylon screws.

Now the Raspberry Pi becomes a perfect audio player.

author: Brahmabeej

description.text:
License: https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/3.0/

I tried to add "This is a Remix" and the option was grayed out, so I looked up the original license (I've never bothered to do this for any piece before). It's tagged as "No Derivatives." I'm not trying to get in trouble, so I'll take down the STL's while I wait for a response from the original creator.

Original: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:522067
Supporting brace: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:938536

I took the original pieces and increased the width from 10mm to 15mm. This allowed me to carve 8 mm shafts throughout the frame. Then I etched M3 hex nut insets for the existing holes and added two M8 hex nut insets at the top of the side shafts. Finally, I created notches for the M8 hex nuts to fit at the ends of the top and bottom rods and the bottoms of the side rods.

Assembly:
First, I installed all the hex nuts. The insets are tight fitting and you will need to pound the nuts into place. I followed this by filing away at the connecting sections to ensure a flush mount.

Next, I assembled the sides. I inserted the 8 mm threaded rod into the chuck of my cordless drill and drilled up from the bottom; stopping at the already inset M8 hex nut and finishing by securing an M8 hex nut at the bottom. After assembling both sides, I attached the top and bottom middle sections to the same side.

Then, using a discarded piece of threaded rod, I drilled into the opposite sidepiece (I was a little over zealous and drilled a bit too far; you can see it in the close up). I then reversed rotation and worked the rod back and forth to clear the shaft. This allowed the piece to easily slide into place. If it is not obvious, you must hold the M8 nuts in place during these assembly steps.

Lastly, I finished by securing the connecting sections with M3 x 16 mm button head hex screws. The rods do a good job of locking the pieces into place. You would probably be fine with just one screw positioned farthest from the rod.

Alternate:
It might be best to exclude the bottom rod. If you plan to use the standard y-axis corners, you will need to cut notches for the M10 y-axis threaded rods to pass through. I plan to remove the bottom rod. The rods add a good bit of heft and the piece feels solid. I do not think removing the bottom rod will negatively affect the overall structural integrity.

2 x 370 mm M8 threaded rod (sides)
1 x 225 mm M8 threaded rod (top)
1 x 220 mm M8 threaded rod (bottom)

remixed_from.author: smokeandlights
remixed_from.title: Roll or spool holder for pegboard

description.text:
This is an original design done in OpenSCAD, but enough inspired by a couple pre-existing Things that I'm more comfortable calling it a remix there-of.

This is a very simple 2-piece spool holder for pegboard. Stick both cylinders into opposite sides of your spool such that the smaller cylinder nests inside the larger one, then hang the whole thing on your pegboard.

It does make use of my Pegboard Base Library since I didn't feel like modeling up the pegs again even though I didn't use most of the base functions. I'm lazy like that.

The two halves are very simple and should print easily on almost anything.

Printer:

BIQU Kossel Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

5%

Notes:

I run these at 0.2 and 5%, but with how simple they are, you can probably do whatever you want. If you do huge layers, you may have to shrink the pegs down a little since they're sensitive to imperfections.

I'm not sure why, but this one sticks to my heated glass bed better than anything else I've ever printed. That's great for curl prevention, but less great when it comes to getting the thing off the bed. If you wait for it to cool, it should pop off easily. If you're impatient like me, crack the cylinder loose, then slide a spatula under it and lift the rest that way.

I've been thinking about spool holders for the pegboard back wall of my workbench for literally weeks. (Yes, I'm really that cool.) Everything I could find here was either too complicated or didn't work or both. I even went as far as remixing one of the complicated designs to make it work better for me and it was still a difficult print (support for the pegs), required outside parts (threaded rod and bearings), had four distinct printed pieces, and still didn't work all that well.

So, I thought to myself, self, let's lay out some parameters and make a better mousetrap...er, spool holder.

Design criteria:

  • Minimize number of printed pieces
  • No non-printed pieces (rods, axles, bearings, pvc pipes, broom handles, etc.)
  • Easy to print with no support / brim / skirt / etc
  • Cheap -- don't waste material
  • Support standard 2"-4" spools
  • Be stable on the wall
  • Be easy to replace spools
  • Don't look like crap

I think this Thing meets the goals. I was hoping to be able to make this as one printed piece, but every one piece design I could find on Thingiverse or think of myself has some combination of lots of wasted plastic, non-printed parts, difficulty to print, support requirements, etc.

These two pieces are easy to print on anything. The single row of pegs is built right on the bed so you don't have to worry about them. The most complex shape in the design is the bent top peg. The only thing that is built to any height is a very structurally sound cylinder.

You don't need any outside parts. The stability comes from the cylinders fitting each other snugly preventing rocking motions and the pegboard itself which prevents the rotating and sliding motion that the nested cylinders allow.

The whole unit assembles on the spool with no connector and hangs on the wall in seconds. There's basically no effort required to change spools. Take spool off wall, pull stand apart, put stand on new spool, put new spool on wall. Done.

For a 2" spool, the cylinders are perfectly nested without anything poking out the end. For a 4" spool, they're still overlapping enough inside the spool to keep everything stable.

Best of all, it works and it doesn't look like crap.

author: Nancy_30kaur

description.text:
Wanted to place a whole mobile phone inside wall-e's eyes, as part of a project I was trying to do. The problem was Wall-E model available online were not hollow to keep anything inside. So downloaded one from google warehouse,
and created hollow inside, made it big enough to fit a samsung galaxy S2, tinkered a little, and generated the STL. Its a closed surface now, with enough space inside to keep a mobile. Before creating a opening (slit or door), I checked the price, and for this size, it was crossing beyond $1000 :( So, have put it on hold, and trying to check what else could be done. This website inspired me and there are lot of cool products. So I wanted to share mine also here. I am a basically a software engineer, and newbie to such designing. So it took a whole day, to come up with this hollow big wall-e, but enjoyed this learning, and all about 3d printing. I wanted to share it here, so it could be useful for someone trying to do similar one.

author: hbc865

description.text:
I was inspired by the PCB workstation project on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2318886 to make a precise test probe holder which uses pogo pins. The target was to test 0201 components so I needed precise, reliable and easy to get spring loaded contacts and pogo pins seem the best choice for this. You can get pogo pins from many places but I used Farnell ones:

  • receptacle for the pogo pin - http://uk.farnell.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/ProductDisplay?catalogId=10001&langId=359&urlRequestType=Base&partNumber=9960260&storeId=10155

  • spring loaded contact - http://uk.farnell.com/harwin/p25-0123/probe-pointed-2-54mm-pitch/dp/9960210

The M3 holding nut is square like this one
https://www.amazon.com/Square-Nuts-M3-Pack-100/dp/B009TDVF80

The result is simple and reliable tester which allows quickly to access the test points, you can attach the base plate to the desk by using Blue Tack (https://www.ebay.com/itm/221964019019) or by tape.

In case you need to access more test points - 5 pogo pins holder is also attached to the project. The vertical columns are tilted on angle to allow the pogo pins to access test points which stay closer than 2.54mm.

Added also a protector sleeve - it covers the pogo pin when not used to prevent it from accidental bending or damaging.

After the details were printed several tooling operations are needed:

  1. Tap a M3 thread on vertical column holders. I use a little ethanol while tapping the thread to prevent the filament from melting and sticking to the tool. Before screwing the screw (M3 x 6) I add a drop of Loctite thread locker http://www.loctite.co.uk/threadlocking-9150.htm

  2. Drilling 7mm hole in the base - to get smooth rotation I use 7mm drill to clean the hole of the base. Details were designed with gaps but frilling is necessary for smooth rotation. After drilling add a small amount of silicon grease for lubrication.

  3. Drill 1.1mm hole for the cable - normally the 3D printer can't keep 1.1mm hole inside the plastic opened so I use 1.1mm drill to clean the hole. This is probably the most delicate operation. Use ethanol for cooling and lubrication during the drilling. I plan to make a new design where this drilling is avoided.

  4. Drill 1.7mm hole for the pogo pin in the arm - this allows the pogo sleeve to be inserted without efforts into the arm.

  5. Insert 1mm diameter wire into the hole of the arm and solder it to the pogo pin receptacle. Notice that the pogo pin is inserted into receptacle at the end (after the soldering) - this prevents the pogo pin from heating during the soldering. If the pogo pin breaks or different end tip is needed (like round corner tip) you can pull out the pin from the receptacle and replace it with new one.

author: blitz1234

print_settings.Notes:: As long as your bed adhesion is decent this should print really easily.  The hardest thing to print are probably the little dogbone connectors.  The actual mating parts are far enough from the bed and the bottom plate is thick enough that some warpage shouldnt cause it to not fit.  The cable holder is the smallest part on the bed, and it's pretty big.  There are overhangs, but besides the screw holes for the inlet and the hole for the probe, they're all well within printable ranges.

description.text:
There are a few other Inkbird cases on Thingiverse, but I designed this one to fit my needs.

1 - It fits in a 120mm build area. So I can print it on my Monoprice Mini.
2 - It has spots for two panel mount outlets, so I can use it for both heating (sous-vide) and cooling (homebrewing).
3 - It's designed so that water can't get in easily. The vent holes are angled down, and the top piece overlaps the bottom.
4 - It has a fused power inlet, just in case.
5 - It doesn't require any hardware to assemble (sort of).
6 - It's designed to be easy to print.
7 - It has a thing to wrap the probe around when not in use.
8 - It will use up some of this ugly yellow filament I have laying around.

You'll only need the following parts -

Inkbird ITC-2000*
Power Inlet*
Two screws from your junk drawer for the inlet.
Surface mount plugs*

Printer:

Maylan M200 / Monoprice Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.175

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print 1 top, 1 bottom, and 4 connectors.

As long as your bed adhesion is decent this should print really easily. The hardest thing to print are probably the little dogbone connectors. The actual mating parts are far enough from the bed and the bottom plate is thick enough that some warpage shouldnt cause it to not fit. The cable holder is the smallest part on the bed, and it's pretty big. There are overhangs, but besides the screw holes for the inlet and the hole for the probe, they're all well within printable ranges.

Construction

First, wire the ITC-2000. There are a ton of guides on how to do this online, and a diagram on the back of the thing, so I'll leave that to you. Make sure you put the probe wire through the hole in the top first though.

Once that's done, put it in the bottom box, and snap the connectors in. They're the odd little pieces you need 4 of. They go into the square holes in the walls. Then snap on the top. You're Done.

* These are Amazon affiliate links.

The FreeCAD files are here in case you need to change something, like you decided to purchase a different inlet or something. Just be warned that the models like to explode when you change almost any dimension. You're better off just patching over whatever area you need to change and drawing a whole new sketch. It's probably the most annoying thing about using FreeCAD part design to do anything that requires more than about 10 steps. Oh, and a guess the fact that changes take forever to apply even on my rather powerful computer.

Depending on your printer, settings, and material you might not need the connectors at all. There's a small annular style snap fit around the outside edge that almost holds well enough on it's own. More rigid plastics might have issues though. The connectors are designed to work with the way printed parts are strongest, so you don't go to pull the thing apart and have the layers seperate instead. I printed in PETG though, so I'm not sure how effective or neccicary it actually is.

author: Nancy_30kaur

description.text: Ball bearing & spring loaded pressure plate for uniform feed regardless of filament thickness

Included in the zip file are:
.par =Solid Edge
.stp
.igs
.stl
For detailed instructions see:
http://www.vinland.com/UM_Extruder_Bearing.html The bearing can be found here for $7.41:
http://www.mcmaster.com/#standard-ball-and-roller-bearings/=i853dw
It is a Dynaroll SMR128ZZ A5 The spring OD is 7.72mm, has 8 turns of 1.14mm wire, and a free length of 20.9mm. Sorry, I do not have any part number since it came from my big junk box... Since I needed to measure the spring used for the Ultimaker Upgrade I documented the steps both for a high accuracy measurement procedure and a simplified one. http://www.vinland.com/Spring-Testing.html Note, the spring for the upgrade is not critical. There is a tremendous adjustment range. I added a section on Extruder Drive Force Measurements:
http://www.vinland.com/Extruder_Drive_Force.html The long screw is 50mm.
The shaft screw needs to be 20mm since the yoke is 18mm.

comments.text: Thanks a bunch for this! finally upgrading from the simple plate after 4 years
comments.author: SunGear

comments.text: Thanks for the great design. The one I had been using previously was very fragile, but this one works great. The only modification I had to do was to lengthen the yoke by 10%.

comments.text: You are welcome Cabonbased.  I am still using the same design.  I have switched from PLA to ABS.  So much nicer to work with and easy to use with additional machining when required.
comments.author: carbonbased

comments.text:
The original from Ultimaker has taken a different approach to this design and holds the bearing within the main frame.
Bertho's instead holds the bearing in the spring loaded clamp.
This difference allows Bertho's setup to put more pressure on the filament than Ultimaker's design.
I tried both setups and I ended up printing one of the pieces of Bertho's design and modifying the acrylic parts of the Ultimaker kit.
I found this solution being the most effective so far :)

It extrudes smoothly for a bit, then I need extra pressure as if to get past some sort of blockage, and then it feeds smoothly again for a while.
comments.author: Bertho

comments.text: My extruder design will avoid the problems of the fixed pressure setting that drastically change vs. filament diameter.  It slips when too thin or deforms the filament if thick.  With the spring-loaded ball bearing the diameter does not matter for the drive mechanism as long as it fits in the Bowden.
comments.author: Jennigma

comments.text: Found the source of friction.  The Bowden tube where it's screwed into my new PEEK insulator appears to have expanded.  I can't push filament through it smoothly when it's off the machine.  I have some 4x6mm teflon tubing so I may rebuild with that to give it more expansion room.
comments.author: Bertho

comments.text: One other possibility is that the threaded section is forcing it to a smaller inside diameter.  Maybe rethread it and do not tighten too much.
comments.author: Jennigma

comments.text: Very nice upgrade.  I am getting more even extrusion and less problems with a filament plug just above the hot end brass tube. I tried using a small diameter bearing without ajustin the yoke and the preformance was worse than with the original Delrin piece.

comments.author: mikeq

comments.text: from what I remember, the force exerted by a spring is given by F=kX where k is the spring constant and x is the deflection. What that means is if you can find a spring that fits the diameter of the yoke, and is roughly the right length, you should be able to change the deflection until you get the right force.  So if you're worrying about finding the right spring, don't - just find whatever you can, and experiment.
comments.author: mikeq

comments.text: Yes, your assumption and suggestions are correct.

description.text:
I had some fun on this project.

Tweaked this design quite alot, modified the base, middle and top decks for reduced plastic usage and lower weight. Modified the main drive screw. Added a DC Motor cover. Created a new leg cam part. Modified the leg gears to include bearings and a smoother cam engagement. Added more surface area to the feet for grip. Split all the parts to fit on a 150x150 print bed size. Doll head optional :) STL files will follow soon.

Once again, a big thank you to my Fiance Trish for all the patience and help with post processing the parts :)

https://youtu.be/MyKalBQwRhw

https://youtu.be/xYCFxPXi5tg

comments.text: I love it.  Would you consider a small tweak (ok, not so small): running each set of legs (left and right) on a separate motor?  This way, a motor control board like a TinySine can be used to run it remotely from a SmartPhone and steer it over a surface.  I also wonder if you can adjust the gear ratios a bit to allow the legs to rise a little more above the ground to facilitate climbing over obstacles.  I know, I know, this is a first cut, but it's so darn interesting, I have to ask....

title: SonicModell F1 Wing Runcam2 Canopy Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I created this Runcam2 mount for the SonicModell F1 Wing. The idea is that the camera mount 'tray' is bolted through the stiff foam canopy and sandwiched by a nut-plate (see photos for my intended installation).

Requires 2 x 14mm (or so) M3 countersunk-head bolts and two M3 nylocs to secure.

I tried to countersink the holes in CAD but since this was a remix the countersinking subtraction just ruined the polygons and created all sorts of errors, so I just countersunk the holes in the camera mount itself on the drill press.

I also used a couple of steel washers between rear of the mount and the foam to lift the back side up a couple of degrees for a slightly more level viewpoint. Also note the canopy removal clip is visible in-frame but I may shorted it by about 50% and it'll be hardly visible.

Camera is secured to the tray with a velcro strap fed through the slot underneath that I've built into the design.

Not perfect, but does the job if you want a secure way of mounting your Runcam2 to the wing in a place that doesn't affect CG too much.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Make sure you enable bridging for perimeters in your slicer as there is a small bridging region where the velcro strap goes.

author: leeph

description.text:
This is a chemical reaction separator-set intended to selectively separate two materials via an actuating rod from one side. The 'Top3.stl' and the 'station.stl' is fixed while the ''Moving.stl" is the slipping-surface intended to interface with an actuating rod.

It was mainly designed as a method to separate effervescent tablets and water for a co2 water rocket. As the driving rod interfaces with the inner plate, once it rotates, the inner plate's flow holes becomes aligned with the bottom plate's flow holes. Thus, water will enter from one chamber to the other chamber to react with the effervescent tablets, generating co2.

It is subject to change as I work further to refine it.

The interfacing rod is (Not included, but it is just a rod with a + shaped cut out at the end. Think of it as an inverse of a Philips screwdriver and a screw) machined out of an aluminum extrusion found at most hardware stores. All the other parts were tested via a FDM printer on PLA.

title: 1988 Dodge Dakota Turn Signal Arm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the tube and mounting flange of the turn signal arm on the steering column of a 1988 Dodge Dakota 3.9 SE.

I designed this because mine had broken off at the base and could not be repaired. Parts for the 1987-1990 model year Dakotas are usually unobtanium, this part included, so I had no choice but to make it myself.

The picture shows a ripple pattern in the print, but this is an issue with my printer, a properly calibrated printer should make this print smooth.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I would recommend using ABS instead of PLA due to heat concerns. Car interiors tend to get hot enough to cause PLA to get soft and fail. A protective paint coating is also recommended to stop UV damage.

The washer is a replacement for the neoprene washer under the end cap if you don't have one of the correct size available. They tend to get oxidized and disintegrate over time, mine fell apart in my hands.
Designed in 3ds max 7.0 over the course of 4 hours.

title: Giant Lego Minifigure : Néo Iron man

description.text:
Giant Lego Neo is an animated minifig scaled to 15x normal size (based on Lego Ironman minifigure).

Neo is probably the tallest 3D printed and automated minifig in the world !

Lot of superpowers !

  • Neo turns his head and track people.
  • Neo can be controled via a touch remote control or via voice commands to lift arms, turn hands or open the visor of his helmet.
  • A system makes it possible to recognize the movement of the right arm and Neo reproduces it.
  • Augmented reality reveals the interior design of the automaton.
  • Neo is accompanied by Jarvis, UI indicating the time, the weather, the activity of the Raspberry, capture of the Kinect, tweets, conferences ...

Datasheet :

  • Body front receive a camera to track people and a 16 Neopixels ring
  • Body back receive 2 servomotors
  • Neck receive 1 servomotor
  • Hips receive 1 RPi
  • Eyes receive 1 or 2 8 Neopixels strip
  • Helmet receive 1 servomotor
  • Head is opened to offer lot of space to put what you want

Code for this giant Lego project is available on Naoned Makers Github : https://github.com/naoned-makers

Raise3D N2 Plus

author: SxCo

print_settings.Notes:: If your filament does not fit the hole you are probably over extruding. Try reducing the flow rate / extrusion multiplier a bit.

description.text:
Usage
Simply clip the clip into your filament one loop before the end, and then thread the end through the hole, pulling it all tight. It will keep it nice and secure and prevents your filament from tangling.

Background
I liked the filament clip design by intofocus however had some issues with it so decided to remake it from scratch.
This one is longer and the holes are a bit bit wider apart for easier handling. It also includes filets at both ends to prevent issues in the hole diameter for people who print with a slight elephant foot and thus would need to scale up the model a bit (but with the result that only one end grabs, the rest sits loose.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

title: FTC Samantha Module and NXT USB Stabilizing Clips

description.text:
Do you ever have trouble with loss of connection with the FTC Robotics field? One problem could be that your USB cable is loose. Use these clips on your Samantha and NXT to hold the cable in place and still comply with the "easily removable cable" rule in the game manual.
Though FTC teams can't use this design directly (new game rules) this design would be easy to modify in order to make it your own.
Best of Luck to all teams!

comments.text: Hi Smokin' Motors!  The rule <r12> "Team designed 3-D printed parts are allowed" could be taken to mean that you (4433) have to design the part for it to be legal, or, that as long as it's designed by an FTC team (a.k.a. not a commercial design) that it would be allowed. This would be an excellent question to bring up on the forum if it hasn't been already. I specifically made this part Creative Commons so everyone could take it and use it. It would be easily modifiable to "make it your own." Best of Luck to your team!</r12>

print_settings.Notes:: I used 3 shells for the first one, but for the 2nd one I only used one and if you are using a filament that has a bit of elasticity it should be able to sort of expand a bit. I used orange color filament to give it a more halloweeny effect and it reminds people of pumpkins.   THE MOST IMPORTANT NOTE IS TO make sure you adjust the size of the hat to your head diameter and size to make sure it fits. I don't want people to waste their time by printing miniature hats which does not fit their heads.  :)

description.text: When you normally think about Halloween, two things come to your mind, horror and weapons or actually three as there is also costume party. So this awesome and horrifying looking hat will make you the star of whichever costume party you are attending for Halloween. I know this hat contains a toy dagger attached to the hat which is why I have made it safer for children to be able to wear it too.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Standard/ 0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used 3 shells for the first one, but for the 2nd one I only used one and if you are using a filament that has a bit of elasticity it should be able to sort of expand a bit. I used orange color filament to give it a more halloweeny effect and it reminds people of pumpkins. THE MOST IMPORTANT NOTE IS TO make sure you adjust the size of the hat to your head diameter and size to make sure it fits. I don't want people to waste their time by printing miniature hats which does not fit their heads. :)

Remove the supports and raft if you added and smoothen the product a bit using filer to give it a nice texture.

To make it more nicer color the eyes black with a permanent marker and your hat is ready to shine.

title: Universal hose adapter & coupler & funnel, and a web service

description.text: New: check the customizer version at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44850 ! This is a parametric hose coupler through a webservice. It can create STL files directly for adpators (adapters?) that couple two hoses or pipes. Hey, you can even make funnels with it! Just provide your own dimensions and get the file!

You could use the provided openscad file and tune it manually... but it will be much easier to get an STL with your settings through this webservice: Just go to https://www.tecrd.com/page/liens/universal_hose_adapter&lang=fr Enter your settings (see the image on the left side for some help), and press a button. Update: Following esteadle's advice, I added so called parametric "barbs" (correct me if I'm wrong). A few parameters changed and the STL generation is now much faster (no more using openscad unions and so). The shape of the main connection was redesigned a bit to make it stronger. Though, the best approach is to make it thicker when:
  • the two cones have very different radii
  • there is a big overhang (thin join makes tricky prints because it also flattens the internal angle). Another parameter would probably be useful to differentiate the two effects.
    • Trial and error seem to be the best way (so far)! Hope it still is OK As long as I have some CPU left the service is free and does not even require an email. Anyhow, please drop me a word if you find this useful, so I know if this kind of tool is worth the time spent on it ;) Idem when you have some requests (eg. a handle for funnels?) Note: I will probably change the URL when I'm done translating my website. As for now, it's an english page within a (mostly) french website, sorry guys! Regards

title: First Gen Mazda 6 Cup Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I will be amazed if anyone who still has a first gen Mazda 6 also has a 3D printer and actually wants this, but I figured I'd post it for posterity if nothing else. The impetus for designing this was that my yeti-style vacuum koozie wouldn't fit in the original OEM cup holder. The tray around the outside at the bottom is for mounting an LED strip. I printed a few mm in clear to make a lit up perimeter.

I no longer have the car (it was a 2006 - the only model that I know this fits), but I made this a while back and used it for a few months before selling the car. I printed with some type of PLA+, I think it was Makergeeks Raptor, but perhaps esun. It worked great until the dead of summer, when it unsurprisingly shrank enough that it took a little force to get my drink in and out. Obviously ABS or another heat-tolerant material would be best.

title: Shift Knob with Mazda Batman Logo M10x1.25
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a shift knob I designed for my previous '06 Mazda 6, using the logo provided by nclontz2, here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:265193.

I believe the shaft size was M10x1.25. The knob is designed to hold the M10 nut captive between the 'main' piece and the 'base', which are secured together with M3 hardware. The emblem press-fits tightly into the cavity on the top of the knob, and should end up even with the surface. The 'bottom seat' piece was added to keep the knob from twisting or abrading the boot when tightening it down.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I found it best to flip the 'base' 180 deg. so only the shallow M10 nut cavity needs supports.
The 'main' knob part should also only need supports in that area. You can let auto supports go all the way up the tube, but it can be a pain to pull them out if they don't separate easily.

title: Bed Levelling Label for Malyan M150

description.text:
Sometimes (in moments of print panic - we've all been there, ;-) I can struggle to remember the correct direction to turn the levelling thumb screws to correctly adjust my printers bed, so I made these little stickers.

There are two version with alternate text to choose from:
UP (bed upward) and DOWN (bed downward).
TO (toward nozzle) and AWAY (away from nozzle).

Each bed levelling label measures 16mm x 16mm. They were designed specifically for the Malyan M150, but should be compatible with any manually adjustable print bed fitted 3D Printer.

Just for info, on the label 'LEVELING' is spelt in the American fashion (rather than the UK version: LEVELLING), which allows the text to be of a slightly larger font size and helps the word remain more easily legible.

Any Ink or Laser Jet

description.text: Print this flat on its side with at least 4 perimeters. You must have well tuned retraction and bridging capabilities.

CostumeChallenge2017

This is a witch's cauldron. You can print the support with a witch extending her hand to you to trap you. The cauldron and the support don't need print support, you only need to open the cauldron (pota.stl) and print it to a 99% of its natural size and then print the witch's support in natural size.

They are big enough for the printer that I usually use. The witch's support is 130mmx170mmx110mm. The cauldron is 100mm diameter, is perfect for keep your candies.

You decide wich is the best filling, but for the witch's support I think that its over 15% the better, for the cauldron is better 25%.

The first design was made with the cauldron rotated. This design is with the cauldron ready to print.

Cauldron and witch creation

First I create the Cauldron with spheres, toroids and cilinder and using boolean actions.
Next I create the witch and extrude it. For the right arm that is extended to you I used a path.
Then I made a cut with the support and the Cauldron.
This is a summary of the creation process

description.text:
Some 3d printed parts for my ebike.
The bike is a HASA comp3.0 mountain bike fitted with a magic-pie-2 motor.
Thing one is a 3 piece junction box which clamps around the handle-bar neck. It is not IP-anything but better than leaving the wires dangling in the wind and rain.
The neck has "saga" printed on it, the neck angle is 100 degrees and the neck tubes are about 35mm OD. The second thing is micro-switch mount to sense the brake lever home position.
Levers with switches were supplied with the motor but the bike has combined gear and brake levers so I had to roll my own solution. Thing-3.
A mount for the cruise control switch. At least that is what golden motor call it. A bit like calling a nail a coat hanger.
It is a throttle lock which does not attempt to hold a set speed.
Pushing the button locks in the current throttle setting and it is cleared using the brake switches or pusing a second time.
The orginal part would not have mounted in this convenient position.
Photos of the older ebike are here.
http://nerdipedia.com/tiki-index.php?page=magic+pie

The box will probably require some work to get it to fit.
My printer was stretching the Z axis so you may have to to rescale it. I supplied two versions of the lid because I had to print mine wider to fit the box.
I had the grind off a little bit of plastic to make it fit - this has been fixed on the files but not tested. For the brake switch I trimmed to switch paddle with a dremel cut off wheel then bound a 1mm carbon fibre rod to it. This was glued in place.
The CF feeler sits at the back of the cable attachment and holds the switch in the "not normal" position. That is the normally closed contacts are held open and close when the brakes are activated.
The switch operates with little movement so the regenerative braking kicks in first without usng the disk brakes. Pulling harder brings the disk brakes into play. Thing three - I filed it out a little and pushed the switch into place. I applied some nail polish in places to bind it a little. The mount pushes onto the bar but I may add a few drops of glue once I'm sure it is OK.

title: SMD SMT  Connectable Container
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
SMD Connectable container

Print as many containers as you like and organize your SMD collection in a professional way.

Print Settings

Before you print be sure you have proper bed levelling on your printer. Elephant foot will cause issues in the connectors. You also need to have your printer's flow/extruder multiplier calibrated properly. The nozzle should be extruding a perfect 0.4mm string. The walls are calculated to a 0.4mm nozzle. Also be sure your retraction settings are well tuned to have a calibrated priming start, possible issues miss start walls or oozing.
Don't rush printing, a minimal z wobble will affect connection.
If you can't connect the boxes, your flow is too high or you have elephant foot issue.

  • Nozzle: 0.4mm
  • Layer Height: 0.2mm
  • Infill: 20% linear
  • Walls: 1.2mm or 3 perimeters
  • Top/bottom: 0.8mm or 4 layers
  • Print speed: 50mm/s ; outside wall: 30mm/s infill:30mm/s
  • First Layer: 30mm/s

Assemble:

The lid and the box can be joined together with a piece of filament as pin.
The first times is a bit ruff to open and close but after some tries it will close with a satisfying click. Use a screwdriver, finger nail, or your SMD too, under the tab to pop open the lid.

comments.text: Heh.  I put in the upstream design: testing this method showed it is pretty awful and not recommended.  the servo has +/-5 degree accuracy, which ruins any attempt to probe the bed.  Have you found a solution to that issue?
comments.author: i-make-robots

comments.text:
This auto-leveling system works perfect.
It is easy to adjust the servo arm. The g-code M280 sends a command to positioning the servo to any entire degree. For example the M280 P0 S90 command rotates the first servo 90 degrees. Find the perfect degree and change the firmware.
You can use Repetier-Host or another software that you prefer to send g-code commands to the printer.
To return to zero degree sends M280 P0 S0.
Visit the site below to adjust perfectly the firmware settings to auto-leveling:
https://3dprinterchat.com/2016/02/bed-auto-leveling-3d-printers/

description.text:
want to create your own 8 bit art to hang on your wall or whatever? Well now you can. I just tested out printing two blocks and connecting them together. The blocks are 1 inch square.

Best part of this method is they can be reused in new designs if you get tired of what you made with them. Just break the connectors and redesign them.

tip: if you find the connectors a bit hard to put inside the block then print them at about 90% and you should be set.

Enjoy and happy printing

title: Tarantula control box and Bracket MKS GEN 1.4

description.text:
A box to house the control board that works as a bracket to stabilize the printer. Designed for the Tevo Tarantula but may work well with other printers too. I made this to house the MKS Gen 1.4 board with tmc 2100 drivers, maximum ventilation and an 80 mm fan for quiet and cool operation. It is also backwards compatible with the mks base that comes with the tarantula.

Many mounting options including using it as a brace to improve printer stability. Extra space available for cable management including cable tie attachment points.

Printer:

Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30-50%
I designed this in sketchup, if anybody wants to make a remix I can provide the original files if that helps.

author: Alasterm

description.text:
BFight 210 TPU Camera mounts. I've made a micro and a default version. The camera mount screws it comes with are awful, you'll need M2x6mm screws for this one. The Micro one works with the Runcam M2 Screws.
Weight difference is 1g with Alu screws (pictured) or 0.5g with Steel ones. This mount holds the fpv camera way better than the sideplates.
These camera mounts are very similar to the ones I made for my 3" frame, the Sperber X34.

Yaaayyyy!!! Halloween's finally here, and that means we had to upload a HALLOWEEN PACK!!! (another yaaayyyy!).

Here you can find a pack of 5 items, they don't need supports and will give to your party that cool touch. When we say party, we say room, shop, restaurant, stand, grave... whatever.

Now let us explain what kind of designs you will find in this pack:

  • We have Wobbly Bones. He is a little shy and doesn't talk, but loves dancing and shaking his bones.

  • A Basic Pumpkin, who doesn't have a costume for Halloween... yet.

  • A Skull Pumpkin. You better not ask where he found that skull... really.

  • A Skull. That's all. Notice that is a little round and have a heart on his nose. Kind of lovely.

  • And a Skull keychain, so thieves won't steal your keys because they'll be so scared that their only option would be to run away. Ok... We can't guarantee that, but isn't it cool? (Btw, did you print our Astroprint keychain yet? ... Really? So what are you waiting for?)

Hope you find them cool... and spooky!

P.S.: We printed them with a 0.3 layer height, and 5% of infill, and they behave perfectly :)

author: BBMBB

description.text:
This is my first design in google sketchup! It is a goat mold for chocolate. My cousin is a chocolate maker (Dr. Chocolate in Seattle) and so I designed a mold for a fundraiser she is donating chocolates to--it is goat themed :)
The piece currently printing out on a Makerbot Cupcake in the Metrix Create:Space with a .35mm extruder head. So far it looks good and the guys and Metrix are extremely supportive and easy to work with.
I'm not sure if the mold will be very usable for chocolate making...I'll post the results later.
I'm open to any comments or suggestions, thanks!

Vertical standing filament stand for those big 1kg spools of filament.
  • Outer diameter of cylindrical holder: 52mm
  • Uses 2 - 4 M3 12mm screws and nuts
  • You can put sticky back rubber pads on the feet to prevent sliding
    • Version 1
  • Deleted.
    • Version 2
  • Freed up the screw holes in the FSHolder part, enabling easier construction.
  • Removed manifold errors.
    • Please feel free to edit my design! It's always interesting to see how people can develop others work! Note: The photographs are of my first model of version 1. It works but the current version is best.

I printed mine using a RepRapPro Ormerod.
  • You will need to either glue the two parts together or use a minimum of 2 (maximum 4) M3 12mm Screws and nuts.
  • I've used 5 sticky back rubber feet to prevent the base part sliding around.

description.text:
Mini Talon Parachute Hatch V3

Installation instructions: Click here!

Introduction

This is a prototype version of a simple servo-controlled parachute/payload drop hatch to be mounted in the bottom rear of an X-UAV Mini Talon. It requires one 9g-Servo (I use a metal gear servo by KST) and a total of three screws (two to hold the servo, one for the hinge) to assemble.

Version History

  • 26.10.2017 - V1

    Initial Release

  • 29.10.2017 - V2

    Lots of improvements

  • 01.12.2017 - V3

    Even more improvements:

    • redesigned servo holder
    • greatly increased size to use all available space
    • increased stability
    • prints with less supports now
    • redesigned hinge: much stronger

Note: This is a work-in-progress! Use it at your own risk.
Print with supports, with the hole up (obviously).

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35% for the main part, 80% for the cover

title: Adjustable Z axis limit switch mount for TEVO Tarantula

description.text:
Adjustable Z end stop for Tevo Tarantula.

New to 3d printing. Tevo Tarantula is my first 3D printer.
The green inductive sensor(SN04) failed me as it never detect bed surface at the same spot.
I also fail to adjust the limit switch precisely. After browsing Thingiverse to find some readily available part to print. I found this and this but they require 4 screws and t-nuts to mouth which I don't have. So, I come up with my own design.

  • Require only 2 M4 screws and t-nut to mount to the frame (It will not twist as protrusion will fitly engage in frame's slot.
  • Adjustable limit switch placement.
  • using M3 screw to adjust end stop.

Hope this would help new Tarantula user. :)

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

No

Supports:

No

0.2mm

These bricks are LEGO Duplo-sized/compatible adapters to Playmobile 123.

To mount your watch to a bicycle handlebar you need a spacer to mimic your wrist.  This one snaps over a 26mm bicycle handlebar, and once the watch is on, stays in place nicely.  It has two cutouts on the inside, one is for flexibility ,the other is to accommodate a brake cable which is attached to the handlebar.
I printed this on a reprap mendel, with very little filler - 0.15% honeycomb.

title: 18mm Probe Bracket for Taz 4/5 with Wrenches UPDATED 10/31/17

description.text:
UPDATE V2 10/31/2017: Revised probe bracket to remove reliefs which cause more printing problems and added gusset for additional strength. Wrench modified to add .5mm to loosen tolerance and make it easier to use. 


Yet another probe mount for Taz Hexagon.  This one has 24mm wrenches for the 18mm inductive probe.  Print two.
The stock M3 screws need to be replaced with longer, 14mm or more M3 screws.
the mounting holes are oversize to be able to align probe vertically if necessary.

I used ABS 30% fill. .3 thick layers.  240/100C.  Rectilinear 3 top and bottom layers.

Photo to follow.

description.text:
This is not a tested model. But maybe someone it fits)
To create this project, I was pushed by Angry Oskie Micro Quad
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2591194

comments.text:
I find it difficult to recommend the material for printing. unfortunately I do not own my own printer. In this thing it was planned to install the ESK over the frame, and the flight controller under it. But I would recommend that you think again before printing this thing. I have a more recent version (which I also did not print yet) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2619526 In this version, the frame is slightly stiffer, and the camera angle is also adjusted. If you do not need propeller protection, you can not print it. But if you still want this particular thing, take a look at the reinforced version of the frame ( "45_V2(reinforced frame)" and "45_V3(reinforced frame)"). If you have any questions, I'll be happy to answer.
P.S. if you still print this thing let me know)))

comments.author: Vasa

comments.text:
Yes, I know that it looks weak, but drew so that it would be possible to pull the wires from the motor by heat shrinkage during assembly (I do not like when the wires hang), I can also draw a reinforced frame.
The blue ring is the same shrink that it planned to draw the motor wires. if I draw a ring around the mounting holes of the FC, then the heat shrinkage will not pull. but this is definitely a weak spot. now I will estimate the strengthened variant.
comments.author: D4SH

description.text:
A simple rocket which is intended to be scaled small for demo prints.
I made it 2 inches tall 1 shell no infill for a fast print that the kids can watch and take a little print home they saw being made. Modeled in Truespace 5

scale as desired,
2 inches tall makes a pretty solid ship
I used one shell, use 2 if you want it sturdier.
I also used no infill, makes a fast print.
you can possibly get away with a 1 inch tall print
but the details get lost.

Some magnetic valves stoppt working because of broken plastic srew-nuts.
I could not get this nuts as a plastic part.
The supplier wanted to sell me the complete inlet with a nut for 60 Euro!
So I printed some nuts to repair the magnetic valves.

description.text: This Reddit figurine is one of a kind!
Remix of the Mosfet holder by Leo_N. It has shorter spacers to allow the mother board screw to tighten the cooling fan mount.

If you have a Taylor 3516 thermometer, you probably know what happens when you drop it. The cover comes flying off and the wires to the thermocouple often break. While this is usually an easy fix with a soldering iron, I'm simply tired of doing it. This cover will keep the thermometer together through nearly all drops in a kitchen.

This cover REQUIRES TPU or another flexible filament. It takes a moderate amount of force to insert the thermometer into the case, but after insertion, the fit is very snug. Without the case being flexible, you will not be able to get the thermometer in the case.

description.text:
Soon after my trip to the coast of the netherlands with my girlfriend we planed to create a memorable decor item. this is now complete.

All you need is the filling of your whishes, an Ikea 365+ Bottle and the printable stand.

Here is the Ikea Bottle in Germany: http://www.ikea.com/de/de/catalog/products/90279719/?cid=ps%7Cde%7Cno_cc_topic%7C4MLRrWwPr0gHjIOUyfOOktEtkrhBQM

comments.text:
This is frickin' awesome! You sole my idea (jk), but actually did it, so kudos to you! Any hints (beside what you have mentioned) for printing?
What program did you use for creating the pieces?
comments.author: tejawood

comments.text:
I used 123D Design, which is quite a simple program.
I designed it to be easily printed at 0.2mm resolution, but for those pieces with severe overhangs (like the gas station) then keep the supports low density... also, make sure to print thin walls, the medicine icons do not print properly with a 0.4mm nozzle unless you print thin walls (S3D and Cura have this setting).
comments.author: tejawood

comments.text: Good deal, thanks!
comments.author: Haratu

comments.text: Are the card pockets sized for sleeved cards?
comments.author: Sigismond0

comments.text:
The card pockets have a 1 mm border around standard card size. This gives them a snug fit that does not damage the cards. The socket on one side of the pocket is designed to avoid damaging cards trying to retrieve them.
If you use card sleeves then my guess is that they will not fit snugly and may provide frustration in retrieving cards... you could, however, pile them in at 90 degrees at an angle upwards.
Unfortunately it is hard to estimate the required border for card sleeves due to different brand having different side allowances depending on quality, plastic welding method, and excess sleeve.

description.text:
Deep in the Golad Mountains of Domaar, in the vale of Prin Guls between the Night Elven realm of Khimzul, and the High Elven realm of Auborlon stand the watchtowers of Prin Guls as a first line of defense against a Night Elven attack.

This is a set of files designed to turn an ordinary Pringles chip can into a piece of 28mm wargaming terrain with a vaguely elven theme. They are the first pieces of a planned modular elven fortress using a combination of 3d printed pieces, Pringles cans, Foam core and card stock. The top parapets are sized just big enough that 7 minis on 1" round bases can fit on the top.

This set of files includes all of the files find for my first version, the Watch Tower of Prin Guls, found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2588030 plus a new parapet and roof piece. I will be adding some additional pieces here in the future as I complete them, including another parapet variant and a balcony. Another planned piece is a Silhouette cutter file for a card stock wrap.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The Tower Base, Tower Top Corbel piece, Tower Roof and Tower Top Parapet pieces are designed to print without supports, but your mileage may vary. I don't know how to re-orient the stl's for correct printing in anything other than my slicer software (Pruse Control) - but basically, rotate the the flattest parts to the bed.

The Tower Window Piece I had a heck of a time getting to print right, and still have a curved back to smoothly attach to the can. I finally wound up using supports and printing it at a 12% angle to get something workable - but I have a lot of ridges.

Step 0: Note

Since Thingiverse keeps losing the pictures I add to this section, I've uploaded a PDF of these instructions with photos to the files.

Step 1: Preparing the Pringles can

The sizing on the Tower Base and Tower Top Corbel pieces are sized to fit around the metal base of the can. This leaves a bit of a gap around the card board that my intention is to be able to use to slip a piece of textured cardstock in between. However, the rolled card board top of the can that the plastic lid fits to is too big, and needs to be carefully cut off.

The next thing you'll want to do is use a marker or pen to put a vertical line on the can so that you can line up the top and bottom pieces. You can use some sort of marking tool or square to do this, but in most cases, the nutrition box and ingredients text of the label itself provides a nice reference. I just lined a ruler up against that, and used a Sharpie.

If you're going to use some sort of card stock or paper around the tube, now is the time to put it on. Makes sure you have some sort of vertical line as a reference.

Step 2: Gluing Everything together

I used 5 minute epoxy to glue everything together. I personally like to orient the can upside down so that the tower can be lifted to place miniatures underneath to show they're inside. If you're worried about the thing tipping over, you can use the can right side up, and fill the bottom with a layer of sand or plaster to weight things down.

When gluing the top parapet piece to the top corbel piece, you'll notice there are three small holes in each piece. These are designed to use short 5mm pieces of 1.75 filament as "keys" so that the two pieces are properly centered.

Glue one or more of the window pieces around the outside as desired.

After gluing, you'll probably need to use something to gap fill because of the extra tolerance I left around the can.

Step 3: Prime and Paint

Prime and Paint as desired

Step 4: Game!

Use it in a game, and share a picture here using the I Made One button.

All of the pieces were pieces were modeled in Fusion 360.

The chips in the Pringles cans were eaten at previous game sessions.
